title: Progress indicators
description: Progress indicators inform users about the status of ongoing processes, such as loading an app or submitting a form.

contentChunks.htmlValue: There are two types of progress indicators: Linear and circular.

contentChunks.footer:
1. 1. Linear progress indicator
2. Circular progress indicator

FlutterPlanned
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Progress indicators look and animate in ways that reflect the status of a process. They are never simply decorative.
  • Progress indicators use animation to capture attention and inform users of an activity’s progress
  • Progress indicators should be applied to all instances of a process (such as loading) in a consistent format (linear or circular)
What's new
• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color

contentChunks.footer: Progress indicators feature new color mappings.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Contents
Usage
Anatomy
Linear progress indicator
Circular progress indicator

contentChunks.footer: A progress indicator used to communicate the status of an ongoing process.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Progress indicators inform users about the status of ongoing processes, such as loading an app, submitting a form, or saving updates. They communicate an app’s state and indicate available actions, such as whether users can navigate away from the current screen.

Progress as a group
When displaying progress for a sequence of processes, indicate overall progress rather than the progress of each activity.

contentChunks.footer: Indicate overall progress of a group
Indicate the progress of each activity in a group

contentChunks.htmlValue:
There are two types of progress indicators:

  1. Linear
  2. Circular

Only one type should represent each kind of activity in an app. For example, if a refresh action displays a circular indicator on one screen, that same action shouldn’t use a linear indicator elsewhere in the app.

contentChunks.footer: 1. Linear indicator  2. Circular indicator

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Each type of progress indicator can be either determinate or indeterminate.

Determinate indicators display how long a process will take. They should be used when the process completion rate can be detected.

Indeterminate indicators express an unspecified amount of wait time. They should be used when progress isn’t detectable, or if it’s not necessary to indicate how long an activity will take.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Determinate progress indicators fill from 0 to 100%.
2. Indeterminate progress indicators move along a fixed track, growing and shrinking in size.

contentChunks.htmlValue: As more information about a process becomes available, a progress indicator can switch from an indeterminate to a determinate state.

contentChunks.footer: A linear progress indicator changes from indeterminate to determinate while loading a screen.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy

contentChunks.footer:
1. Track
2. Indicator

contentChunks.htmlValue: Progress indicators are made of a track (which is not visible for circular progress indicators) and an indicator.

Track

The track is a fixed width rule, with set boundaries for the indicator to travel along.

contentChunks.footer: Track of a linear progress indicator.
Track of a circular progress indicator, which is not visible and is implied by the path of the indicator in motion.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Indicator

The indicator animates along the length of the track.

contentChunks.footer: Indicator animating along the track of a linear progress indicator.
Indicator animating along the track of a circular progress indicator.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Linear progress indicators
Linear progress indicators display progress by animating along the length of a fixed, visible track. The behavior of the indicator is dependent on whether the progress of a process is known.

contentChunks.footer: Linear progress indicators are composed of track and indicator.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Linear progress indicators can be determinate or indeterminate.

Determinate operations display the indicator increasing from 0 to 100% of the track, in sync with the process’s progress.

Indeterminate operations display the indicator continually growing and shrinking along the track until the process is complete.

contentChunks.footer: Determinate linear progress indicator.
Indeterminate linear progress indicator.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Placement

The placement of a linear progress indicator can indicate the scope of a process. For example:

  • Expanding items can place a linear indicator along their expanding edge to draw user attention to where new content will appear
  • A linear indicator at the center of the screen can indicate loading all screen content
  • A linear indicator attached to a container, such as a card, can indicate the process applies to that particular item (and that interaction with the rest of the UI is possible)

contentChunks.footer: Expanding items can place a linear indicator along their expanding edge to draw user attention to where new content will appear
A linear indicator at the center of the screen indicates loading all screen content
A linear indicator attached to a container indicates the process applies to that particular item (and that interaction with the rest of the UI is possible)

contentChunks.htmlValue: Circular progress indicators

Circular progress indicators display progress by animating along an invisible circular track in a clockwise direction. They can be applied directly to a surface, such as a button or card.

On Android, the “swipe to refresh” gesture displays a circular progress indicator to indicate that the UI is being refreshed.

contentChunks.footer: Circular progress indicators are composed of an invisible track and an indicator.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Circular progress indicators can be determinate or indeterminate.

  • Determinate circular indicators fill the invisible, circular track with color, as the indicator moves from 0 to 360 degrees.
  • Indeterminate circular indicators grow and shrink in size while moving along the invisible track.

contentChunks.footer: Determinate circular progress indicator.
Indeterminate circular progress indicator.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Placement

Circular progress indicators are positioned to indicate the process that they represent.

  • When centered on the screen, they indicate the initial loading of screen content.
  • When placed above or below existing content, they draw attention to where new content will appear.

contentChunks.footer: A circular indicator centered on screen indicates an initial loading process.
An indicator appears where new items will appear, at the end of the current items grid.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Paired with other components

A circular indicator can be integrated into a button or actionable icon to express a connection between an interaction and a specific item. They are typically used to express when an interaction, such as clicking a button again, isn’t available.

They should be used for short, indeterminate activities (between 2-5 seconds). Longer activities may require alternate methods of communication, such as snackbars or notifications.

contentChunks.footer: Use circular indicators for short, indeterminate activities (< 5 seconds) requiring user attention.
Don’t apply progress indicators to every button in your app. They can unnecessarily interrupt the user’s task.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Use cases

Users should be able to 

  • Navigate to the loading indicator with assistive technology
  • Understand what progress the indicator is communicating
Interaction & style
The active indicator element (which displays progress within the progress indicator) provides visual contrast of at least 3:1 against most background colors.

contentChunks.footer: The progress indicator provides visual contrast of at least 3:1 against most background colors.

contentChunks.htmlValue: When integrated into another component, such as a button, make sure that the active indicator element provides visual contrast of at least 3:1 against the other component.

contentChunks.footer: Ensure the indicator’s color provides at least 3:1 contrast against the other component.
Avoid integrating a progress indicator with another component where it does not provide at least 3:1 contrast.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Labeling elements

Because the progress indicator is a visual cue, it should have an accessibility label to assist users who cannot rely on the product's visual interface.

Use an accessibility label to describe the role and meaning of the progress indicator, including what content is being loaded.

contentChunks.footer: A label on a determinate progress indicator on a screen which is loading a news article.
A label on an intedeterminate progress indicator on a screen which is loading a set of podcast episodes.
